Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South2nd FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2596special.collections@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-12-21T20:05:10Describing Archives: A Content Standard Materials are in English.
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Women Hospital Workers Oral History Collection
Sexton, Patricia Cayo
OH.006
2 Linear Feet in 1 letter manuscript box, 1 half letter manuscript box, and 2 flat boxes.
67 audiocassettes
1979 This collection contains interviews of hospital workers conducted in 1979, including both recorded interviews on audiocassettes and interview transcripts. The interviewees are primarily women, with a few men represented as well. They are members of SEIU Locals across the United States, and include nurses, nursing attendants, lab supervisors, researchers, therapists, food service workers, custodians, business agents, secretaries, and more. They discuss topics such as experiences of sexism and racism on the job, working conditions, union organizing, the women's movement, maternity leave, pay inequities, and workplace hierarchies. The collection includes both recorded interviews on audiocassettes and interview transcripts. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Patricia Cayo Sexton in circa 1979. The accession number associated with this collection is 1950.129.
Historical Note
Healthcare workers first joined Service Employees International Union (SEIU) in 1941, when workers in San Francisco organized their hospital and won their first contract. Interview participants represented in this collection come from SEIU Locals across the United States.
Many of the interviews reference George Hardy's leadership as President from 1971-1980. During his tenure, the union saw rapid growth and organized its first local union of physicians. Merges and affiliations accounted for much of the growth during this time. There is also much discussion of the 1966 hospital workers strike in Los Angeles, which led to the Meyers-Milias-Brown Act, the first public employee law on collective bargaining in California.
In addition to union organizing, history and structure, the interview participants discuss at length their thoughts on the women's rights movement and experiences of sexism and racism at work. Major themes include paid maternity leave, discrimination faced by pregnant women, pay inequity, and workplace sexual harrassment. The participants also discuss their relationship with the Coalition of Labor Union Women (CLUW), a national organization that formed in 1974 to advocate for women's issues within the labor movement.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Women Hospital Workers Oral History Collection; OH 006; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
In April 2021, box numbers were attached at interview level. In December 2022, the collection was arranged and described by an archivist.
Scope and Contents
This collection contains interviews of hospital workers conducted in 1979, including both recorded interviews on audiocassettes and interview transcripts. The interviewees are primarily women, with a few men represented as well. The creator of this collection and conductor of the interviews are unknown. In some interviews with women participants, the first name of the interviewee is omitted from source materials and therefore unknown.
The interviewees are members of SEIU Locals across the United States, and include nurses, nursing attendants, lab supervisors, researchers, therapists, food service workers, custodians, business agents, secretaries, and more. They discuss topics such as experiences of sexism and racism on the job, working conditions, union organizing, the women's movement, maternity leave, pay inequities, and workplace hierarchies. Some interviews include multiple interviewees, and are based on a particular topic such as the women's movement. Not all audio recordings have a transcript, and not all transcripts have an audio counterpart.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Patricia Cayo Sexton, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
Arrangement
Interviews are arranged alphabetically by the interviewee's last name. Some interviews include multiple participants, and are based on a particular topic such as the women's movement; in these cases, they are arranged alphabetically by the subject of the interview.

Hospitals -- Employees -- Interviews. Labor unions Labor unions -- Organizing. Women's rights -- United States -- 20th century Women employees.
